case_name: M. S. M. Sharma v. Sri Krishna Sinha

facts.text: Petition No. 176 of 1959 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 176 of 1959. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Petitioner is a journalist by profession and functions as the Editor of the Searchlight, an English daily newspaper published from Patna in the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner, who is a journalist by profession and is functioning as the Editor of the Searchlight , an English daily newspaper published from Patna in the State of Bihar,

facts.text: Petitioner published in Searchlight issue dated May 31, 1957 an account of the debate in the Bihar Legislative Assembly on May 30, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: impugned the validity of the proceedings before the Committee of Privileges and prayed for restraining the opposite party... from proceeding against the petitioner for the publication in its issue dated May 31, 1957, of the Searchlight an account of the debate in the Legislative Assembly, Bihar, on May 30, 1957.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 122 of 1958 heard and determined by Supreme Court on December 12, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: By this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution the petitioner raises almost the same companytroversy as had been done in Writ Petition No. 122 of 1958, which was heard and determined by this Court by its judgment dated December 12, 1958,

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 106 of 1959 heard by Supreme Court on November 10, 11 and 12, 1959, but withdrawn before judgment.

anchor.surface_text: and by Writ Petition No. 106 of 1959, which was heard by this Court on November 10, 11 and 12, 1959, but which did number reach the stage of judgment by this Court, inasmuch as the petitioners Advocate requested the Court to permit him to withdraw the petition and the Court allowed the prayer and permitted the petitioner to withdraw the petition.

facts.text: In M. S. M. Sharma v. Sri Krishna Sinha, Supreme Court held that under Art. 194(3), House of Legislature has powers, privileges as House of Commons at commencement of Constitution, including prohibiting publication of reports.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case have been stated in great detail in the majority judgment of this Court delivered by S. R. Das, C. J., in M. S. M. Sharma v. Sri Krishna Sinha  1 . ... This Court held in effect that under Art. 194 3  of the Constitution a House of a Legislature of a State has the same powers, privileges and immunities as the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom had at the companymencement of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner received notice on January 5, 1959 that breach of privilege case would be considered by Committee on February 3, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On January 5, 1959, the petitioner received a numberice that the case of breach of privilege against him would be companysidered by the Committee of Privileges of the Assembly on February 3, 1959.

facts.text: Hearing postponed from date to date until petitioner filed Writ Petition No. 106 of 1959 in August 1959.

anchor.surface_text: That hearing was postponed from date to date, until in August, 1959, the petitioner filed his petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Committee of Privileges meeting held on August 10, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The prayer made in the petition was that the proceedings of the Committee of Privileges at its meeting held on August 10, 1958,

facts.text: Bihar Legislative Assembly reconstituted the Committee of Privileges.

anchor.surface_text: After the petitioner had made his writ application to this Court as aforesaid, the Bihar Legislative Assembly reconstituted the Committee of Privileges of the Assembly,

facts.text: Member sought to move motion for revival and re-reference of breach of privilege matter.

anchor.surface_text: and on that very date a member of the Legislative Assembly sought to move a motion in that Assembly for revival and re- reference of the matter of the alleged breach of privilege by the petitioner.

facts.text: Speaker deferred ruling on objection to motion.

anchor.surface_text: Some members of the Bihar Legislative Assembly objected to the motion being moved and the Speaker of the Assembly deferred giving his ruling on that objection.

facts.text: Speaker referred two questions to Advocate General of Bihar on October 20, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of some of the members of the Assembly, the Speaker of the Assembly referred two questions to the Advocate General of Bihar for his opinion on the floor of the House on October 20, 1959, namely,  1  whether it was open to the Assembly to debate on an issue which might be sub judice in view of the writ petition aforesaid filed by the petitioner in the Supreme Court under Art. 32 and  2  whether the matter which was dead by reason of prorogation of the House several times companyld be, legally revived and restored.

facts.text: Advocate General of Bihar gave opinion in House on October 20, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On October 20, 1959, the Advocate General of Bihar attended the House and gave his opinion, which it is number relevant to state here.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 106 of 1959 withdrawn on November 12, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Writ Petition, 106 of 1959, was heard in part and allowed to be withdrawn, as indicated above, on November 12, 1959.

facts.text: Petitioner received fresh notice on November 24, 1959 from Secretary of Legislative Assembly to show cause by December 1, 1959 for breach of privilege.

anchor.surface_text: On November 24, 1959, the petitioner received a fresh numberice from the Secretary of the Legislative Assembly, opposite party No. 3, calling upon the petitioner to show cause on or before December 1, 1959, why appropriate action should number be recommended against him for a breach of the privilege of the Speaker and the Assembly.

facts.text: Committee of Privileges adopted motion at meeting on November 23, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner again instituted proceedings under Art. 32 of the Constitution companyplaining that the motion adopted by the Committee of Privileges of the Bihar Legislative Assembly at its meeting held on November 23, 1959,

facts.text: Petitioner impugns proceedings before Committee of Privileges, Chief Minister as Chairman, Secretary of Bihar Legislative Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: impugned the validity of the proceedings before the Committee of Privileges and prayed for restraining the opposite party, namely, the Chief Minister of Bihar as Chairman of the Committee of Privileges, Bihar Legislative Assembly, Committee of Privileges and the Secretary of the Bihar Legislative Assembly,

facts.text: Bihar Assembly prorogued several times between May 31, 1957 and November 23, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: after several prorogations, the previous proceedings for breach of privilege were dead... between May 31, 1957 and November 23, 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 1, 1960 by SINHA C. J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. August 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA C. J.-

facts.text: Petition dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, for the reasons given above, numbergrounds have been made out for the exercise by this Court of its powers under Art. 32 of the Constitution. The petition is accordingly dismissed.

facts.text: Sri Krishna Sinha is Chief Minister of Bihar and Chairman of Committee of Privileges.

anchor.surface_text: the Chief Minister of Bihar as Chairman of the Committee of Privileges, Bihar Legislative Assembly,... In Writ Petition No. 122 of 1958, Sri Krishna Sinha, Chief Minister of Bihar, was impleaded as opposite party No. 1

facts.text: Petitioner contends proceedings by Chief Minister are mala fide.

facts.text: No order as to costs in previous petition.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this Court, in view of the judgment of the majority, dismissed the petition, but made numberorder as to companyts.

issues.text: Whether the present writ petition is barred by the principle of res judicata

anchor.surface_text: The Government Advocate of Bihar, on behalf of the opposite party, has contended, in the first instance, that the present writ petition against the parties, namely, the Chairman and the Members of the Committee of Privileges, respondents 1 and 2, is barred by the principle of res judicata and, therefore, not maintainable.

issues.text: Whether res judicata does not apply due to reconstitution of the Committee of Privileges

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the petitioner it was contended by Mr. Basudeva Prasad that respondent No. 2, the, Committee of Privileges, has been reconstituted as aforesaid after the first decision of this Court which is sought to be availed of as res judicata and that therefore the rule of res judicata is inapplicable.

issues.text: Whether the privilege under Article 194(3) is subject to fundamental right under Article 19(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner had the fundamental right under Art. 19 1  a  of the Constitution to freedom of speech and expression which included the freedom of publication and circulation and that the Legislature of the State of Bihar could not claim any privilege contrary to the right thus claimed. In effect, it was contended that the privilege conferred on the Legislature of a State by Art. 194 3  of the Constitution was subject to the fundamental right of a citizen contained in Art. 19 1  a .

issues.text: Whether the proceedings for breach of privilege are dead after several prorogations of the Assembly

anchor.surface_text: finally, it was contended that after several prorogations, the previous proceedings for breach of privilege were dead and the House of the Assembly had, therefore, no power or jurisdiction to issue the fresh notice in accordance with the motion of November 23, 1959, reviving the proceedings.

issues.text: Whether the procedure adopted inside the House of the Legislature was not regular and calls for judicial interference

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that the procedure adopted inside the House of the Legislature was not regular and not strictly in accordance with law. There are two answers to this contention, firstly, that according to the previous decision of this Court, the petitioner has no the fundamental right claimed by him. He is, therefore, out of Court.

issues.text: Whether there is violation of Article 21 by threat to personal liberty through privilege proceedings

anchor.surface_text: the motion adopted by the Committee of Privileges... amounted to an abridgement of his fundamental right of speech and expression guaranteed under Art. 19 1   a  of the Constitution and was an illegal and mala fide threat to the petitioners personal liberty in violation of Art. 21 of the Constitution of India

issues.text: Whether mere non-compliance with procedure vitiates proceedings where jurisdiction exists

anchor.surface_text: Courts have always recognised the basic difference between complete want of jurisdiction and improper or irregular exercise of jurisdiction. Mere non- compliance with rules of procedure cannot be a ground for issuing a writ under Art. 32 of the Constitution vide Janardan Reddy v. The State of Hyderabad .

issues.text: Whether the breach of privilege proceedings are too stale after more than three years

anchor.surface_text: It was also sought to be argued that the subjectmatter of the proceedings in contempt, whatever it was, took place more than three years ago, and that, therefore, it has become much too stale for proceeding against the petitioner in contempt.

issues.text: Whether grounds exist for interference under Article 32

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, for the reasons given above, no grounds have been made out for the exercise by this Court of its powers under Art. 32 of the Constitution. The petition is accordingly dismissed.

arguments.claim: Petitioner has fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(a) to freedom of speech including publication of legislative proceedings, which overrides privilege under Art. 194(3)

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner had the fundamental right under Art. 19 1  a  of the Constitution to freedom of speech and expression which included the freedom of publication and circulation and that the Legislature of the State of Bihar could not claim any privilege contrary to the right thus claimed. In effect, it was contended that the privilege conferred on the Legislature of a State by Art. 194 3  of the Constitution was subject to the fundamental right of a citizen contained in Art. 19 1  a .

arguments.claim: Majority decision in previous case (M.S.M. Sharma) is wrong

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before us that the petitioner, as a citizen of India, had the fundamental right of freedom of speech and expression which included the freedom of obtaining the earliest and most correct intelligence of the events of the time including the proceedings of a Legislature and publishing the same and that no Legislature of a State could claim a privilege so as to curtail that right. It was, therefore, contended that the majority decision of this Court in Pt. M. S. M. Sharma v. Shri Sri Krishna Sinha 1 was wrong

arguments.claim: House of Commons at commencement did not have privilege to prohibit accurate reports

anchor.surface_text: It was further contended that even if the House of a State Legislature had the same powers, privileges and immunities as those of the House of Commons, those will be only such as were being actually exercised at the date of the commencement of the Constitution and the right to prevent publication of its proceedings was not one of those powers, privileges or immunities.

arguments.claim: Present writ petition barred by res judicata

anchor.surface_text: The Government Advocate of Bihar, on behalf of the opposite party, has contended, in the first instance, that the present writ petition against the parties, namely, the Chairman and the Members of the Committee of Privileges, respondents 1 and 2, is barred by the principle of res judicata and, therefore, not maintainable.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: gs in accordance with its rules of business. Even though it may number have strictly companyplied with the requirements of the procedural law laid dow

arguments.court_reasoning: Same parties/representatives; same issues fully contested previously; applies general principles beyond CPC s.11

arguments.claim: Writ cannot issue against individual members or House for exercise of privileges

anchor.surface_text: His contention also is that the writ cannot issue either against an individual member or against the House of the Legislature as a whole in respect of what has been done by it in exercise of its privilege of prohibiting or, at any rate, controlling the publication of its proceedings.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e Assembly was prorogued several times between May 31, 1957 and November 23, 1959. In our opinion, there is numbersubstance in this companytention, fo

arguments.claim: Res judicata applies despite reconstituted Committee as it represents same Assembly

anchor.surface_text: Would it make any difference that though opposite party No. 2 is the Committee of Privileges, its personnel is different from that of the Committee of Privileges constituted as it was in 1958 ? In our opinion, it does not make any difference. So long as the Assembly remains the same it is open to the Assembly to reconstitute its Committees according to the exigencies of the business of the Assembly.

arguments.claim: Art.212 bars courts from inquiring into legislative procedure

anchor.surface_text: Article 212 of the Constitution is a complete answer to this part of the contention raised on behalf of the petitioner. No Court can go into those questions which are within the special jurisdiction of the Legislature itself, which has the power to conduct its own business.

arguments.claim: Prorogation interrupts but does not terminate privilege proceedings; can be revived

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no substance in this contention, for the simple reason that the prorogation of the Assembly does not mean its dissolution. The House remains the same only its sessions are interrupted by prorogation of the House according to the exigencies of public demands on the time and attention of the members of the Assembly and the volume of business of the Assembly itself.

arguments.claim: No grounds for exercise of Art.32 powers; petition dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, for the reasons given above, no grounds have been made out for the exercise by this Court of its powers under Art. 32 of the Constitution. The petition is accordingly dismissed.

arguments.claim: Distinction between lack of jurisdiction and irregular exercise; latter not ground for writ

anchor.surface_text: Courts have always recognised the basic difference between complete want of jurisdiction and improper or irregular exercise of jurisdiction. Mere non- compliance with rules of procedure cannot be a ground for issuing a writ under Art. 32 of the Constitution vide Janardan Reddy v. The State of Hyderabad.

holdings.text: The present writ petition is barred by the principle of res judicata as the questions were already determined in previous petition No. 122 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the questions determined by the previous decision of this Court cannot be reopened in the present case and must govern the rights and obligations of the parties which, as indicated above, are substantially the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Previous decision fully contested same issues involving same Assembly and Committee; general res judicata principles apply beyond CPC s.11; cites Raj Lakshmi Dasi.

holdings.text: Res judicata applies despite reconstitution of Committee of Privileges with different personnel, as it represents the same Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: Would it make any difference that though opposite party No. 2 is the Committee of Privileges, its personnel is different from that of the Committee of Privileges constituted as it was in 1958 ? In our opinion, it does not make any difference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Committee is agency of same Assembly; personnel change irrelevant; Assembly transacts business through committees.

holdings.text: Petitioner has no fundamental right under Art.19(1)(a) threatened by privilege proceedings, as per binding previous majority decision.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest, therefore, that the petitioner has no fundamental right which is being threatened to be infringed by the proceedings taken by the opposite party.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Previous decision in M.S.M. Sharma binding; cannot reopen; Art.194(3) privileges prevail over Art.19(1)(a).

holdings.text: Courts cannot inquire into validity of legislative proceedings on grounds of procedural irregularity per Art.212.

anchor.surface_text: Article 212 of the Constitution is a complete answer to this part of the contention raised on behalf of the petitioner. No Court can go into those questions which are within the special jurisdiction of the Legislature itself

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.212 precludes judicial review of internal legislative procedure; legislature conducts own business.

holdings.text: Art.21 not violated by privilege proceedings as no deprivation of liberty without procedure established by law.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest, therefore, that the petitioner has no fundamental right which is being threatened to be infringed by the proceedings taken by the opposite party.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No fundamental right exists per previous holding; proceedings within jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Prorogation of Assembly interrupts but does not terminate breach of privilege proceedings; can be revived by fresh motion.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no substance in this contention, for the simple reason that the prorogation of the Assembly does not mean its dissolution. The House remains the same only its sessions are interrupted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prorogation suspends business per May's Parliamentary Practice but does not quash contempt/privilege matters permanently; cites analogy to bills.

holdings.text: Mere procedural irregularity or non-compliance does not vitiate proceedings where jurisdiction exists; no ground for writ.

anchor.surface_text: Courts have always recognised the basic difference between complete want of jurisdiction and improper or irregular exercise of jurisdiction. Mere non- compliance with rules of procedure cannot be a ground

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between jurisdictional error and irregularity; cites Janardan Reddy; legislature has complete jurisdiction over privileges.

holdings.text: Timeliness or staleness of breach of privilege proceedings is matter for legislature to decide, not court.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this is also a matter within the jurisdiction of the legislature which must decide whether or not it was recent enough to be taken serious notice of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court not concerned with punishment or seriousness; legislature's prerogative.

holdings.text: No grounds made out for exercise of powers under Art.32; petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, for the reasons given above, no grounds have been made out for the exercise by this Court of its powers under Art. 32 of the Constitution. The petition is accordingly dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; no infringement of fundamental rights; res judicata and procedural bars apply.

precedents.citation: M. S. M. Sharma v. Sri Krishna Sinha  1

anchor.surface_text: M. S. M. Sharma v. Sri Krishna Sinha  1 . In the opening paragraph of this Courts judgment aforesaid, the parties before the Court have been enumerated and the anomaly pointed out. This Court held in effect that under Art. 194 3  of the Constitution a House of a Legislature of a State has the same powers, privileges and immunities as the House of Commons of the Parliament of the United Kingdom had at the companymencement of the Constitution. The House of Commons at the relevant date had the power or privilege of prohibiting the publication of even a true and faithful report of proceedings of the House and had a fortiori the power or privilege of prohibiting the publication of an inaccurate or garbled version of such debate or proceedings.

precedents.case_name: M. S. M. Sharma v. Sri Krishna Sinha
precedents.cited_proposition: Under Art. 194(3), a State Legislature has the same powers, privileges and immunities as the House of Commons at the commencement of the Constitution, including power to prohibit publication of even true and faithful reports of its proceedings.
precedents.cited_holding: The House of Commons had the power or privilege of prohibiting the publication of even a true and faithful report of proceedings of the House.

precedents.citation: Pt. M. S. M. Sharma v. Shri Sri Krishna Sinha  1

anchor.surface_text: Pt. M. S. M. Sharma v. Shri Sri Krishna Sinha  1  was wrong In this companynection it was also companytended that  1  1959 SUPP. 1 S.C.R. 806. the rule of companystruction adopted by this Court in its pre- vious decision had been wrongly applied. It was further companytended that even if the House of a State Legislature had the same powers, privileges and immunities as those of the House of Commons, those will be only such as were being actually exercised at the date of the companymencement of the Constitution and the right to prevent publication of its proceedings was number one of those powers, privileges or immunities.

precedents.case_name: Raj Lakshmi Dasi v. Banamali Sen
precedents.cited_proposition: Principle of res judicata applies to a question raised and decided after full contest even if the first tribunal lacked jurisdiction or subject-matter not exactly same.
